Posts.Content: I take these tablets.  Two a day - one in morning and one in evening.
Posts.Title: Repeat prescriptions from GP

Posts.Content: Haven't got much practical advice for you apart from be kind to yourself, listen to your body and rest when needed.  Nothing else matters in the scheme of things.  Chemo can be evil but remember you will have your life back at the end of it.  You can do this, you are stronger than you think.  It certainly made me a stronger person and having gone through it I do not take any s**** from anyone any more.  I had three cycles of FEC and 3 cycles of Docetaxel.  I was isolated in hospital for 8 days because my blood count dropped too low and I became nutropenic during cycle 5.  I really did not want cycle 6 and my oncologist even considered whether to stop it but it went ahead and I survived.  I finished in April and have now completed treatment having finished radiotherapy at the end of July.  Sending you positive thoughts and virtual hugs.  Stay strong and hang in there.
Posts.Title: chemotherapy - I'm struggling

Posts.Content: Funny how a diagnosis affects plans.  I was all set to go to Japan last Christmas to see my new grandson.  That was until a routine mammogram changed my life.  But hey, two operations, 6 cycles of chemo and 15 sessions of radiotherapy later and I am at the moment cancer free.  I am planning that trip for February.  Hope I get there this time.  One cloud on the horizon is that the hubby has a lump on his neck which is being investigated.  He has had an endoscopy which was fine.  He had a scan a week ago and we go for the results on Christmas eve.  The consultant is not unduly worried and thinks it may be a cyst but I am not counting my chickens as I have been here before.  Let's hope it is not an unwanted present!  I don't want to have to cancel another trip.
Posts.Title: How life has changed

Posts.Content: I ordered several bras from Asda after my surgery in May and have also had two mastectomy swimsuits from them.  I am very pleased with them all.  They are pretty, fit well although can be a bit of a squeeze to get form into cup.  They do matching knickers  and they are so much cheaper than speciality websites.  I shall be ordering more soon :)
Posts.Title: ASDA post surgery bras

Posts.Content: Have my last radiotherapy today and I am not sure how I am feeling.  I want to celebrate that after two operations, chemo and radiotherapy I am seeing light at the end of the tunnel.  I want to be able to get on with my life and have a break from hospitals for a little while but I am not sure what happens next.  I had a CT scan two weeks ago of chest, abdomen and pelvis as a follow up to chemo but have not had any results yet.  I think I had the scan because I have a rare form of cancer.  I had one before I started treatment and it was clear apart from a tiny speck in my lung which my oncologist wasn't worried about.  I know they are probably just keeping an eye on me but I feel I daren't be happy yet because if I am I will get some bad news.  Stupid I know!  Can anyone enlighten me as to what happens after all planned treatment is finished?  How often do you have check ups etc.  I should probably phone my oncologist but half of me doesn't want to because of scan.  I am going on holiday in a couple of weeks and don't want anything to spoil it.
Posts.Title: Treatment finished. Where do I go from here?

Posts.Content: Thanks both.  No I don't intend to try to do too much.  I am lucky that I work in a school and so have 6 weeks' holiday anyway at the moment.  I am not sure I am going to go back in September yet as it is a very, very busy job and I know once I commit to going back even on a phased return it will be full on and feet won't touch the floor.  In fact I am seriously considering retiring early and having plenty of time to smell the flowers and all the other things that I want to do.  Life is too short!!!
Posts.Title: Treatment finished. Where do I go from here?

Posts.Content: Oh dear!  Sorry about your break.  I am sure it was the last thing you wanted.  Hope you are soon mended.  Take it easy.
Posts.Title: Treatment finished. Where do I go from here?

Posts.Content: Hi  I know that feeling!  I have my last radiotherapy tomorrow (hurray) and have had a wide margin, a mastectomy and 6 cycles of chemo.  On the one hand I feel like celebrating but on the other I had a CT scan 2 weeks ago as a follow up to chemo and have not had any results yet.  I don't want to tempt fate and  celebrate too soon then get some news from the CT scan that I don't want to hear.  I would like a little respite at the least from treatment.  Also I am going on holiday in three weeks for rest and relaxation and I don't want anybody to tell me bad news re scan before I go.  I think it is because when I was diagnosed (after a routine mammogram) I was supposed to be going to see my new grandson in  Japan and obviously could not go.  I am thinking that I do not want history to repeat itself.  I am also unsure as to what happens next now planned treatment as finished.  I know they will be keeping an eye on me especially since my cancer was a rare one with a higher chance of returning, but how that works I am not sure.  Anyway great that you are at end of treatment and good luck for future.  Enter your message...
Posts.Title: All my treatment nearly finished, weird feeling.

Posts.Content: 'Hi, please don't panic.  As others have said there are many of us with spread to lymph nodes.  I had a lumpectomy in November last year and auxiliary clearance.  I had cancer cells in 14 out of 31 nodes removed.   I had a scan (chest, abdomen and pelvis) before I started chemo and one again in July this year.  Both were clear.  They found out on examination of the tumour that I had a rare cancer that was aggressive and had a higher chance of coming back so I had to have a further operation - full mastectomy followed by chemo and radiotherapy.  But.... as I say my scans have been clear including a bone scan so there is no sign of the disease elsewhere.  Who knows what the future will bring but I could get hit by a bus tomorrow so we should all enjoy life to the full.  Good luck with the rest of your treatment.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer has spread to nodes, panicking

Posts.Content: Hi  I am allergic to penicillin and paracetamol but I don't think it follows that you are automatically allergic to both.  I got sick of people querying the allergy to paracetamol while having treatment so I think it is quite unusual.  I think they tell you not to take the painkillers as they can all lower your temperature. I was hospitalised with a high temperature/virus and low blood count during cycle 5 and they would not give me any ibruprofen because it would mask the temperature.  Just had a fan directed at me!!  I think as long as you take your temperature before taking any tablets then you are fine.

Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: Very true with regard to taste changing with each round so try and see is my advice.  I found jelly and soup  good especially when mouth was sore. Pineapple juice, ginger tea and biscuits.  I am also now addicted to Haribo sweets - I used to eat the sour ones in copious amounts. A good moisturiser - I had a skin reaction which looked a bit like sunburn on my hands and feet.  Udderley Smooth Cream - commonly known as moo cream is excellent.  You can get it on the internet but my chemo unit got me some on prescription. Difflam mouthwash is good if you have a sore mouth. Be prepared as steroids can cause constipation - tins of prunes etc.   Good luck with the chemo.   Stay strong.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the support. Prognosis is good. Just waiting for an op date.
Posts.Title: Here we go again.

Posts.Content: Just when thought we could settle down after a year of treatment for breast cancer and wham hubby is diagnosed with thyroid cancer. Leave us,alone bloody cancer!!!!  Bit of a shock as consultant was sure it was a benign cyst until it was removed and biopsied. 9mm T1. Glad he chose to have it removed and at least it is very treatable. He will probably be having whole thyroid out now.  Oh well my turn to give him a bit of support and TLC.  Would just liked to have a bit of normality back especially since I was beginning to feel a bit better. Never mind. Onwards and upwards.
Posts.Title: Here we go again.

Posts.Content: I had this with docetaxel too but on my hand and around my elbows. It was like a burn that was red tight and cracked. Also itchy. My face an neck went a bit red but not as bad as hands etc.  I used Udderley Smooth cream. My Chemo nurses gave me a prescription but you can buy on line. It is amazing.  I also had anti histamine when I was in hospital because I was neutropenic.  Docetaxel affected me really badly.  All my nails fell off too and I had constant thick pglegm ib my throat but hey I got through it.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel - face and neck red - have you experienced this?

Posts.Content: Hi  I finished my radiotherapy last week too.  I was given a sheet which had radiotherapy department phone number in case I needed to ask them anything, advice about ongoing side effects for next couple of weeks and it also said that I would have a follow up appointment in 12 weeks.  Funny feeling isn't it?  I had a CT scan three weeks ago as a follow on from chemo. No results yet so part of me wanted to celebrate finishing treatment and the other part was saying don't tempt fate.  Silly I know.  Onwards and upwards!
Posts.Title: what happens after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi   I finished my treatment in July.  I have not worked since the start of treatment.  I am lucky  in that I work in a school and had full pay for 6 months and then half pay for 6 months.  When I went onto half pay I had advise from a McMillan financial advisor and I claimed Employment Support Allowance.  I get £216 per fortnight and I am in the support group which means that you do not have to have an interview to judge whether you are fit for work.  My half pay runs out this month so I am having to go back to work.  I do not want to as I still get very tired and have neuropathy in my hands and feet as well as creaky joints due to Anastrazole.  But hey ho will see how it goes.  Good luck with the claim.
Posts.Title: Exhaustion after chemo

Posts.Content: I had to take 8 steroids the day before, the day of and the day after Docetaxel.  My understanding was that it was to lessen side effects and reduce the risk of allergic reaction as it is very powerful drug.  I also had an anti sickness pill to take an hour before I had the treatment and pills to take home in case needed.  I believe I was given more anti sickness intravenously.  I was never sick whilst on chemo but sometimes felt queasy.  I did not put on any weight - in fact I lost a stone and a half as I did not feel like eating.  Partially I lost my appetite and mainly because everything tasted so foul.  I finished chemo at the beginning of April and find I still cannot eat big meals.  Bonus as I needed to lose some weight - not ideal way of doing it though!!
Posts.Title: steroids?

Posts.Content: Hi just wanted to let you know I am feeling very much the same.  You think great treatment is over but then it hits you.  I liken it a to a little bit of post traumatic stress.  You have so much going on and support whilst undergoing treatment and then when it is over feel that you are on your own.  I could cry some days but I think that is a little bit due to the Anastrazole I am on too.  My situation is not helped by the fact I am under the infamous Stafford hospital (who I must say were brilliant whilst being treated).  The Trust has been dissolved and it now comes under North Staffs area.  This means that the oncologist that I was seeing and trusted no longer works at the hospital as the hospital where she is based in under a different authority now.  The replacement I saw on Friday was a man who obviously had not read my notes as he asked how my chemo was going when I finished in April and finished all treatment in July.  He also gave me a prescription for a couple of items which, when I took them to the pharmacist she questioned the dose and instructions on both.  Added to this since my surgery in May I have always had discomfort where one of the drains was fitted. I thought this was just the healing process but I had some inflammation around the mark so asked the breast care unit to look at it.  I still had a stitch in place.  They removed most of it but skin had grown over some of it so could not remove all of it.  Again when I went for my post surgery check up it was a different surgeon to the one that did the mastectomy and I had to tell him that my history.  I had had a WLE first then needed a mastectomy later.  He thought I had just had the WLE.  He also missed the stitch when he checked how I was healing.   Does not exactly fill me with confidence.  May ask to be seen by the surgeon who did the mastectomy in future.  At lease I trust her.   Also had my annual mammogram this afternoon.  First one since treatment finished.  I was OK about it until I was actually having it done then it sort of hit me.  Was a bit wobbly when I came out.  It was this time last year that I was diagnosed after a routine mammogram.  Fingers crossed it is OK this time.  Hope you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: feeling sad and angry after having had breast cancer

Posts.Content: I get insomnia on Anastrazole too.  I can go to sleep fine but then wake up around 3.00 am absolutely wide awake and with my brain unable to switch off.  I also get restless legs from nerve damage but do not want to take medication for it.  I have found the last couple of nights that taking ibuprofen  before bed has helped me sleep.
Posts.Title: feeling sad and angry after having had breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello everyone.  I have not posted for quite a while but wonder if anyone has experienced cellulitis?  I had micro papillary breast cancer.  Had a lumpectomy, chemo, mastectomy and auxillary lymph node clearance, radiotherapy finishing in July 2014. Since then I have suffered from peripheral neuropathy which makes soles of feet burn, restless legs and numbness in toes and fingertips.  At the end of January I contracted a bacterial infection which led to cellulitis of the arm.  I was hospitalised for three days on IV vancomycin antibiotics then had another 12 days of 1800 mg clindamycin a day.My arm is much improved but still feel very tired.  My main worry though  is that I am shaky inside.  My GP thinks it may be anxiety. I am having a hard time at work and cannot face returning yet and because the cellulitis appeared overnight I think it gave me a scare which brought back all that we have been through these last three years. My husband has also had cancer last year.  I am wondering however whether the feeling of internal shakiness and sometimes shaky hands may be after effects of the antibiotics or they have worsened the neuropathy. I also get stabbing pains in my fingertips of the affected hand and a feeling the same as restless legs but in my arms.  Sorry for the long post but this constant tremor is driving me mad.  If anyone can shed any light I would be grateful.  I am seeing my oncologist in a couple of weeks so I will discuss it then.  Thanks all.
Posts.Title: Cellulitis after effects

Posts.Content: My hair is just growing back so I am too rocking the Sinead O'Connor look but to be honest I did not ever mind being bald. I am going to keep my hair short as everyone has said it suits me.  I shaved my hair off as soon as it started falling out and only wore hats and scarves because I did not want other people to feel embarrassed when they saw me.  I had some brilliant pleated turbans which I had lots of compliments about but I bought them from my local market so I could not recommend a website.  I found them easier than scarves as you could just pop them on and off when you were answering the door etc.  They fit snugly and I never worried about them coming off.  If you can find some they are worth investing in.  I hardly wore my wig as I hated it.  It was itchy and too hot.
